facts.text: Chapter V-A was introduced in the Bombay Municipal Corporation Act, 1888 by Maharashtra Act 14 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Chapter V-A was introduced in the Bombay Municipal Act, 1888 by Maharashtra Act 14 of 1961. That chapter companytains sections 105A and 105B.

facts.text: Chapter V-A contains sections 105A and 105B granting powers of eviction to the Commissioner for unauthorised occupation of corporation premises.

anchor.surface_text: According to the provisions of those sections the Commissioner in relation to premises belonging to or vesting in, or taken on lease by the companyporation

facts.text: Unauthorised occupation is defined as occupation without authority or continuance after authority expired or determined.

anchor.surface_text: Unauthorised occupation is defined as occupation by any person of companyporation premises without authority for such occupation and includes the companytinuance

facts.text: Under section 105B, Commissioner can issue notice to vacate for arrears of rent over two months, sub-letting, waste, contravention of terms, or public interest.

anchor.surface_text: Under section 105B the Commissioner, by numberice served on the person in unauthorised occupation, companyld ask him to vacate if he had number paid

facts.text: Before eviction order, Commissioner must issue show cause notice specifying grounds.

anchor.surface_text: Before making such an order the Commissioner should issue a numberice calling upon the person companycerned to show cause why an order of eviction

facts.text: Person concerned can file written statement, produce documents, appear by advocate.

anchor.surface_text: The person companycerned can file a written statement and produce documents and is entitled to appear before the Commissioner by advocate, attorney or pleader.

facts.text: Appeal from Commissioner's order lies to principal Judge of City Civil Court.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal from every order of the Commissioner lies to the principal Judge of the City Civil Court or such other judicial officer as the principal Judge may designate.

facts.text: Bombay Government Premises Eviction Act, 1955 provisions similar but for Government premises, competent authority not lower than Deputy Collector or Executive Engineer.

issues.text: Whether the choice between the two alternative procedures not being vested in the same authority results in a violation of Article 14

anchor.surface_text: It would not however be contended, on this basis that the choice between the two alternative procedures is not vested in the same authority and that therefore there is no violation of Art. 14.

issues.text: Whether, when the question is under Article 14, mere fairness of the special procedure is enough to avoid violation of the equality clause where two procedures are available, one more drastic

anchor.surface_text: It would not also be contended on behalf of the respondents that even where two procedures are available against a person, one substantially more drastic and prejudicial than the other and there is noguiding principle or policy laid down by the legislature as to when one or the other shall be adopted. there would still be no violation

issues.text: Whether the two procedures are so disparate substantially and qualitatively as to lead to unequal treatment under Article 14

anchor.surface_text: What has to be considered is Whether there is equality before law and therefore the question whether the two procedures are so disparate substantially and qualitatively as to lead to unequal treatment, has to be asked and answered.

issues.text: Whether the impugned provisions of Chapter V-A of the Bombay Municipal Corporation Act and the Bombay Government Premises Eviction Act violate Article 14

anchor.surface_text: The challenge against the constitutional validity of Chapter V-A of tile Municipal Act and Government Premises Eviction Act must, however, be rejected.

issues.text: Whether the classification for selective application of the special procedure to occupiers of municipal or government premises has intelligible differentia and rational nexus to the policy and object, given guided discretion to authority

anchor.surface_text: No classification can be logically complete or precise. Life is not capable of being divided into water-tight divisions and categories. The legislature can therefore do no more than define broad categories and indicate the policy and purpose underlying the legislation and leave it to a stated authority to make selective application of the law

issues.text: Whether there is clear guidance provided by the legislature as to when the special procedure should be adopted and when the ordinary procedure

anchor.surface_text: There is thus clear guidance provided by the legislature as to when the special procedure should be adopted and when the case should be, left to be dealt with under the ordinary procedure and the impugned provisions do not suffer from the vice of discrimination.

issues.text: Whether one procedure is substantially more drastic and onerous than the other merely because one is before civil court and other administrative tribunal

anchor.surface_text: There is noformula by which it can be said that one procedure is substantially more drastic and onerous than the other. It does not follow that merely because one procedure provides the forum of a civil court while the other provides the forum of an administrative tribunal that the latter is necessarily more drastic

issues.text: Whether the special procedure set out in Chapter V-A of the Municipal Act is substantially more drastic and prejudicial than the ordinary procedure of civil suit

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, it is apparent that the special procedure set out in Chapter V-A of the Municipal Act is not substantially more drastic and prejudicial than the ordinary procedure of civil suit.

issues.text: Whether the procedure prescribed by the impugned provisions is onerous or drastic when compared with that contained in the Civil Procedure Code

anchor.surface_text: I agree that the writ petitions be dismissed, but I would base my conclusion on the ground that the procedure prescribed by the impugned provisions is not onerous or drastic when compared with that contained in the Civil Procedure Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Impugned provisions upheld under Art. 14 as classification of public premises occupiers has intelligible differentia and rational nexus to speedy recovery; guided policy on when to use special vs ordinary procedure; special procedure provides adequate safeguards comparable to civil suit.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, it is apparent that the special procedure set out in Chapter V-A of the Municipal Act is number substantially more drastic

holdings.reasoning_summary: Special procedure includes notice, hearing, documents, legal representation, summons powers, appeal to judicial officer (Principal Judge City Civil Court), High Court remedies under Arts 226/227; not onerous given public interest in speedy recovery.

holdings.text: There is clear guidance provided by the legislature as to when the special procedure should be adopted and when the case should be left to be dealt with under the ordinary procedure and the impugned provisions do not suffer from the vice of discrimination.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Public premises occupiers form class for speedy eviction; dual test satisfied - intelligible differentia (public vs private property), rational nexus to expeditious recovery for public use; guided by statutory policy.
